_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sorrento Lactalis, Inc. (Sorrento) proactively used the OSHA Process Safety Management program required under 29 CFR 1910.119, in conjunction with the additional off-site considerations addressed in 40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D, as an accidental ammonia release prevention program.  These documents are considered as working documents by Sorrento management, and are used by facility personnel as the procedural standards for preventing accidental releases of ammonia.

     Emergency response policies for the Sorrento facility include an integration of the plans required under 29 CFR 1910.38(a) "Emergency Action Plan",  40 CFR Part 355 "Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know", 1910.119 "Process Safety Management" and 40 CFR Part 68 "Risk Management Program".  The integration of these programs for the Sorrento facility increases the usefullness of the emergency preparedness activities by decreasing the burden associated with maintaining multiple programs.  In gneral, Sorrento performs minor emergency response measures with properly trained in-house personnel, however, local emergency response agencies handle all major emergencies.  Community notifocation policies are in place in the event of an emergency with potential off-site impacts.

     The regulatory stationary source is considered to be the entire Sorrento Lactalis, Inc. facility located at 4912 E. Franklin Road in Nampa, Idaho.  The stationary source is involved in the manufacture of various cheese products.  Ammonia liquified under presssure is the only regulated chemical exceeding a threshlod quanity under 40 CFR Part 68.

     The accidental release prevention program integrates the OSHA Process Safety Management required under 29 CFR 1910.119 and the additional off-site considerations addressed in the 40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D, as an accidental release prevention program.  One of the most important aspects of the prevention program is strict adherence to the mechanical integrity portion of the PSM pr

ogram, using specific standrads established for the ammonia refrigeration industry by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR).

     There have been no reportable releases at the Sorrento facility over the last five years.
